subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Jupiter is shrinking?

More stuff about Jupiter,  "would display metallic properties, losing  hold=
 
over their electrons._[1]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metallic_hydrog=
en#cite_note-0)   Since then, metallic hydrogen has been described as "the =
holy 
grail of  high-pressure physics"._[2]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki=
/Metallic_hydrogen#cite_note-1) "he  cloud layer is only about 50 km deep, =
and 
consists of at least two decks of  clouds: a thick lower deck and a th=
in clearer 
region. There may also be a thin  layer of _water_ 
(http://en.=
wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_(properties))  clouds  underlying the ammonia laye=
r, as 
evidenced by flashes of _lightning_ (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li=
ghtning)  
detected in the  atmosphere of Jupiter. (Water is a _polar molec=
ule_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_molecule)  that can  carry a char=
ge, so it is capable 
of creating the charge separation needed to  produce =
lightning.)_[29]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-elkins-t=
anton-28)   These 
electrical discharges can be up to a thousand times as p=
owerful as  lightning on 
the Earth._[42]_ (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ju=
piter#cite_note-41)   The 
water clouds can form thunderstorms driven by th=
e heat rising from the  
interior._[43]_ (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupi=
ter#cite_note-42) "
Well, if that is all true, there is some work that has =
to be done to make  
Jupiter a place to sustain life, it has water, but the=
 electrons and protons 
are  just floating around, and things would need to=
 be fuzzed together. 
Electrons  within the plasma sheet generate a strong =
_radio_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio)  signature that produces  bur=
sts in the range of 0.6=E2=80=9330 
_MHz_ (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Her=
tz) ._[59]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-58) "    Too m=
uch to post here, but when you all get a 
chance read up on Jupiter, things=
  are not fuzzed, but the elements are all 
there, it has 63 moons, some of=
 which  may also have water. sf
 


In a message dated 2/23/2011 9:33:32 P.=
M. Eastern Standard Time,  
SnowfireL@... writes:

 
 
 
Interesting th=
ings about Jupiter:  "Although Jupiter would need to  be 
about 75 times as=
 massive to fuse hydrogen and become a _star_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wik=
i/Star) , the smallest _red dwarf_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_dwarf=
)  is only about 30  percent larger in radius than Jupiter._[27]_ 
(http://=
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-26) _[28]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.or=
g/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-27)   Despite this, Jupiter still radiates 
more h=
eat than it receives from the Sun.  The amount of heat produced inside 
the=
 planet is nearly equal to the total _solar radiation_ 
(http://en.wikipedi=
a.org/wiki/Solar_radiation)  it  receives._[29]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/=
wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-elkins-tanton-28)   This additional heat radiation i=
s 
generated by the _Kelvin-Helmholtz  mechanism_ (http://en.w
ikipedia.org=
/wiki/Kelvin-Helmholtz_mechanism)  through _adiabatic_ 
(http://en.wikipedi=
a.org/wiki/Adiabatic_process)   contraction. This process results in the pl=
anet 
shrinking by about 2 cm  each year._[30]_ 
(http://en.wikipedia.org/w=
iki/Jupiter#cite_note-guillot04-29)   When it was first formed, Jupiter was=
 much hotter 
and was about twice its  current diameter._[31]_ 
(http://en.=
wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter#cite_note-30) "
